Three's A Crowd

31/03/2012

Yorkshire Voices was a wonderful showcase of the vast arrays of talent the North has to offer.

Image by

By undefined undefined

York Literature Festival 2012, Day 2: Friday 30 March Venue: Jacob's Well, Micklegate Time: 7.30pm-10.00pm The medieval parish rooms of Jacob's Well in York provided the perfect setting for the Yorkshire Voices poetry reading. This extremely well organised event by the York Poetry Society was only complimented by the dark beamed ceilings and the creaky floor underfoot. Oz Hardwick's work felt particularly at home in the antique surroundings; with his first poem taking inspiration from the Anglo-Saxon poem The Seafarer. The self-proclaimed formal poet captured his audience with the sonnet The Seafarers return. The Leeds Trinity professor spoke about how using old forms of poetry, such as sonnets, were like "entering an old building and having a look around", The Seafarers Return seemed to embody perfectly the haunted feeling that one often gets when entering such a place. Family ties, much like with the first poet, were clearly a huge influence on Hardwick and he spoke passionately about his Grandfather who introduced him to poetry. The Good Shepherd, which was inspired by his Grandfather, with its injection of foreign words portrays the distance that he spoke about having with his grandfather, but the collage of memories that are depicted made the subject matter poignant, and Hardwick's warm countenance when expanding on memories and stories only added to the nostalgic air of the poem. Hardwick introduced all of his poems with anecdotes that were told with good humour and always provided an interesting insight into his thoughts, past or inspirations. A History of Butterfly Collections was, he explained, based on his own childhood experiences and the poem encapsulated brilliantly childhood naivety; innocence of the damage your actions can do. This contrasted with the more light hearted, humorous anecdotes such as the introduction he gave to Hitchhiking in French Cinema, he spoke of one of his first experiences abroad when he was in a car with a French man and how he had never seen someone gesticulate so much whilst driving. The story was greeted with a ripple of laughter through the small audience. He then progressed to introduce poems of a more sexual nature. The poem 'Book Lover' was introduced through talking about books as the "cultural DNA of western society" and went on to amusingly talk of the advantages of using books rather than kindles; all the while encouraging audience interaction. He ended on the title poem of his new collection The Illuminated Dreamer which he delivered passionately and was filled with beautiful imagery depicting a kind of immobilising dreaminess alongside ardent embraces. Hardwick's delivery and engagement with the audience only added to the rich language that his poems use in abundance. His poems covered a wide span of topics which made listening to him easy, enjoyable and enthralling. The first speaker of the event, Will Kemp, contrasted greatly with the easy going manner of Hardwick. Kemp spoke in a monotonous voice with short introductions to his poems. His book is dedicated to the memory of his mother and father and their deaths seemed to resonate deeply throughout all of his poems. His monotonous voice added to the haunted feeling in many of his poems. In particular the poem After my father died had a dark and moving edge especially when he later spoke of how his father's death was "sudden and unexpected". Whilst Hardwick and Borthwick both seemed to enjoy engaging with the audience with anecdotes and stories; Kemp was very frank and honest. Whilst introducing the poem Fountains Abbey, a poem that he said was about memories of him and his mother, he confided in the audience that he doesn't miss her in any "sentimental way"; though the repeated simple lexis at the start of each stanza 'you would love.. you would ask...' would suggest the opposite. His manner though blunt, was effective in terms of the content of his poetry. Kemp later admitted that he had laid out some of the poems on the page so that the white of the page would look like snow and therefore give the poem a colder sense. However, as one shrewd member of the audience pointed out, this means that certain poems would be more effective when read not listened to. The final poet of the evening was the bubbly Pat Borthwick who successfully took the audience through a huge variety of emotions using her poetry. Her Celtic style was evident through the rhyming schemes of the poetry and the half Irish poet used her own life experiences to create both funny and moving pieces. Borthwick began with a short poem named Until I Did which she introduced with a funny anecdote about when she was younger and more innocent than her brothers. The poem was centred around her discovering her brother's porn collection and not fully understanding what it was. This amused the audience greatly and was well received. After a couple of light hearted poems she then moved on to the controversial subject of Badger baiting. A countrywoman herself, Borthwick is clearly well informed on the subject and spoke of a desire she had had for a while of wanting to write about it. She took the voice of a badger and used short, sharp, staccato stanzas with disjointed words which were successfully contrasted with long, dreamy stanzas representing the memories the badger had. The poem was moving and through the use of the badger's voice allowed the audience to empathise with the creature. She progressed to read a mixture between emotional poetry and funny bursts of humour. She managed to involve the audience through asking questions and being genuinely interested in the answers. Her second to last poem named The Day Before was about the attack on the Twin Towers. She spoke of how it had taken her ten years to write and had tried to avoid any sensationalism. However the poem didn't fully avoid this trap and by the end it seemed to have succumbed to the contrived poignancy that so many poems based on this subject do. The three completely different tones of each of the poets added greatly to the evening and provided much entertainment. Not only were their poetic styles different but also their personalities and the way in which they addressed the audience. The evening was a wonderful showcase of the vast arrays of talent that Yorkshire has to offer.
